<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module2_mcq_q32')" data-correct-answer="B">
<strong style="display: block;">
In performance evaluation, the concept of "alpha" is widely used to measure the value added by a portfolio manager beyond passive exposure to systematic risk. 
Which of the following statements best captures the meaning of alpha in the context of asset pricing models such as CAPM?
</strong>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q32" value="A"> A. Alpha represents the portion of return explained by the sensitivity of the asset to the market portfolio (beta).</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q32" value="B"> B. Alpha measures the abnormal return earned by a portfolio or security, beyond what would be predicted by its exposure to systematic risk.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q32" value="C"> C. Alpha is the risk-free rate used as the baseline in the CAPM equation.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q32" value="D"> D. Alpha is the market risk premium that compensates investors for holding risky assets.</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q32" value="E"> E. Alpha is the weighted average cost of capital (WACC) adjusted for the firm’s leverage.</label><br>
</form>
<div id="feedback-module2_mcq_q32" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: B. Alpha represents the excess return beyond what is explained by exposure to systematic risk (beta). 
A positive alpha suggests outperformance relative to CAPM predictions, while a negative alpha suggests underperformance.
</div>
